thread.section_title: Las Vegas Sun Stories: Arts & Entertainment
thread.title: Strip Scribbles: Channing Tatum’s ‘Magic Mike’-inspired Las Vegas show?
thread.title_full: Strip Scribbles: Channing Tatum’s ‘Magic Mike’-inspired Las Vegas show?

title: Strip Scribbles: Channing Tatum’s ‘Magic Mike’-inspired Las Vegas show?
text:
Launch slideshow » 
We have three Wicked Whispers & Racy Rumors on this day: 
Hollywood hunk Channing Tatum ’s deal for a “Magic Mike” revue at the former Body English in the Hard Rock Hotel apparently came thisclose to a firm deal, but the plans are said to have gone up in smoke at the last moment. 
Next year’s Fourth Annual Academy of Country Music Party With a Cause is no April Fool’s Day joke as it stretches out to three days at Las Vegas Festival Grounds opposite SLS Las Vegas alongside Circus Circus. 
Carrie Underwood will kick it off April 1, Dierks Bentley headlines on the second night, and Kenny Chesney closes it out April 3. 
Las Vegas supermodel and John Legend ’s wife Chrissy Teigen is joining glamour girl Tyra Banks for her new ABC daytime TV show “The Fab Life,” and Strip star-chef Steve Martorano will be their guest next month with his Italian recipes. 
PERMANENT WAX: Flamingo headliners Donny & Marie Osmond will have a permanent home on the Strip — at least in wax if not real life. The sibling duo announced Thursday that they’ll continue their residency at Flamingo through at least 2016 and probably beyond, then came word that they will be immortalized at Madame Tussauds at the Venetian, the first figures in the New Year. 
The brother-and-sister singers have been involved with their wax lookalikes since the inception. Their sitting took more than three hours per person, with the studio team taking approximately 300 measurements. Their measurements have been used to sculpt their figures in clay by hand, then covered in a plaster cast. The clay was removed from the casts and poured in and allowed to cool. Launch slideshow » 
The next few weeks will be spent meticulously inserting each hair by hand, which is customary for the Madame Tussauds studio team. Finally, the figures will be fitted with acrylic eyes and teeth, while countless layers of tinted paint will be applied to build up skin tones and replicate their faces. 
We’ll get the first photos from the sittings here at Vegas DeLuxe in early November. Donny & Marie resumed at the Flamingo on Thursday night through Nov. 14 before setting out on their Christmas tour, then solo shows before returning here in February. 
MR. CHOW ARRIVES: It’s official that the seventh restaurant for global dining legend Mr. Chow will open at Caesars Palace in December. I dined at Michael Chow ’s original in London in 1968 and the two he opened in New York. He went on to open in Miami, Malibu and Beverly Hills, as well. 
Known primarily for expensive menu items and celebrity clientele, Michael is the master who brought Beijing duck, green prawns and hand-pulled noodles to the dining scene. The second-story restaurant overlooking Garden of the Gods will seat more than 250 guests. 
The recipe for his all-time favorite “fried seaweed” on the menu as “Gambei” is still kept secret to this day, but I can tell you that it’s not dug up from the sea as popular myth has it! In fact, it’s fresh collard greens fried in peanut oil, then sliced and diced. I’m betting that once you eat Michael’s duck in the thin, tiny, tortilla-like pancake wrappers, you’ll be sold for life. 
CONGRATULATIONS: The Oasis at Gold Spike downtown celebrated its first anniversary Thursday. Owned and operated by Downtown Project, the boutique hotel was opened after a multimillion-dollar renovation last year. Built in 1962, the revitalized property’s original charm has been enhanced by modern luxuries, custom art instillations and playful environment. 
Oasis has become known as downtown’s ultimate crash pad offering 44 uniquely designed rooms and suites. The three-story hotel also will be seen on Season 31 of MTV’s “The Real World” as filming takes place at Oasis’ adjoining property, Gold Spike. 
And to Nove Italiano at the Palms with chef Marlon Simbulan serving a nine-course meal to celebrate its ninth anniversary. Launch slideshow » 
DAYCLUB DELIGHTS: Season 5 of wild-party madness is underway at Ghostbar Dayclub in the Palms. This Saturday, professional party photographer Kirill Was Here is the host. New this year for GBDC is a selection of packages of extraordinary experiences that range from $10,000 to a whopping $1 million. 
The Make it Rain celebration at $10K gets you 10 bottles of Cristal, 10 bottles of Dom Perignon, 20 bottles of 40-ounce Malt Liquor, 100 cheeseburgers and $1,000 in dollar bills to make it rain. A Social Media Butler will post all the fun for a day. For $25,000, you can be the DJ for the day. A Ghostbar patio marriage is $20,000, your newlywed names will go up on the Palms marquee, and you get 10 bottles of Cristal to drink during a two-night Sky Villa. May I have the first twerk on the GBDC floor? 
The $50,000 Pizza package might only include 10 boxes of pizza and 10 cases of King Cobra malt liquor to wash it down, but add in a new Rolex — and time is money! Finally, you’re asking, what do you get for $1 million? It’s a party monster package with round-trip private jet transportation to and from Las Vegas with Porsche Turbos at your disposal over the four-night stay in the Hardwood Suite and dinner for 10 with star-chef Barry S. Dakake of N9NE Steakhouse in his private dining room. The GBDC patio is yours and yours alone with a $50,000 drink credit and that butler to record every cherished moment of the extravaganza. 
Robin Leach of “Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous” fame has been a journalist for more than 50 years and has spent the past 15 years giving readers the inside scoop on Las Vegas, the world’s premier platinum playground. 
Follow Robin Leach on Twitter at Twitter.com/Robin_Leach . 
Follow Las Vegas Sun Entertainment + Luxury Senior Editor Don Chareunsy on Twitter at Twitter.com/VDLXEditorDon . Body English 
Though masculine in lines and furnishings, there are sensuous feminine touches to be found within Body English's black leather upholstered walls and oversized booths. 
Guests walk down a long flight of stairs which leads to the main entrance of the club. The first focal point that catches the eye is a larger-than-life million dollar, color-changing crystal chandelier that hangs over the main dance floor, offering a touch of elegance while simultaneously offering just enough lighting to create an intimate ambiance. 
Around the perimeter of the upstairs level are the main bar and a number of VIP godfather booths, ideal for elite groups. On the main dance floor, additional VIP booths made of elegant black leather circle the room, giving guests the best view of all the action. Complete with its own DJ booth, bar and waitress staff, the room known as The Parlor, which is adjacent to the main dance floor, also offers an intimate experience for separate parties. 4455 Paradise Road Las Vegas , NV 89169 702-693-4000 Hard Rock Hotel & Casino 
Arguably one the coolest joints in town, the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino houses some of Vegas' best entertainment, restaurants and nightlife. 
At Hard Rock, it's all about the music. From the light fixtures made out of drum cymbals and guitar shaped door handles to stage costumes and tools of the trade of legendary musicians displayed on the walls, the hotel screams rock and roll. The Hard Rock's Joint has hosted some the biggest names in music — from The Who to Bob Dylan to hometown heroes, The Killers. Aside from the music venues, the pool at the Hard Rock is one of its biggest attractions. Spread out over 4.7 acres, the pool area features swim-up blackjack, a bar and grill, private cabanas, a bevy of secluded nooks, a waterfall and an extensive live music venue with a dance floor. During the summer, the pool transforms into the Rehab club on Sunday afternoons.
The resident nightclub Body English fuses European elegance with a rock star bachelor pad and it often a hot spot for visiting celebs and popular DJs. Vintage rock memorabilia lines the walls at Wasted Space, Hard Rock's anti-club. 
Restaurants at Hard Rock are just as hip as the rest of the casino. Pink Taco serves up Mexican dishes, as well as a Central American and Caribbean menu. Nobu, one of five worldwide Japanese-specialty restaurants from famed Nobu Matsuhisa, satisfies a different taste. For round-the-clock cuisine, Mr. Lucky's 24/7, is sure to ease your appetite even after a Vegas-all-nighter. 4455 Paradise Road Las Vegas , NV 89169 702-693-5000
